Award.AwardTitle: Categorification and 3-Manifold Invariants in Algebraic Geometry
Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposal is to construct 3-manifold invariants using tools and techniques from algebraic geometry and geometric representation theory. Given a Lie algebra one can define a numerical invariant of 3-manifolds called the Witten-Reshetikhin-Turaev invariant. It is an open problem to lift these to homological invariants of 3-manifolds. This is analogous to the way (singular) homology of topological spaces lifts the Euler characteristic. In earlier work of the PI jointly with Joel Kamnitzer they were able to do this for complements of links inside the 3-sphere when the Lie algebra is sl(n) and the link labeled by fundamental representations. To do this they used certain (derived) categories of coherent sheaves on flag-like varieties and the hope is to generalize this approach to other 3-manifolds. Their constructions were algebro-geometric but used many techniques from representation theory. Inspired by representation theory the PI plans to develop other tools to study varieties and their categories of coherent sheaves. For example, he plans to study actions of the Heisenberg Lie algebra on categories of sheaves on Hilbert schemes.

The simplest example of a 3-manifold is the 3-dimensional world we live in. A little more complicated is what you obtain by cutting out a doughnut or perhaps an object with more holes. However, there are even more complicated 3-manifolds which are harder to describe. A fundamental problem in low-dimensional topology is how to tell whether two given 3-manifolds are "the same" or not ("the same" has a very precise mathematical definition in this case). A 3-manifold invariant is a tool for doing this. Their construction leads one to study other fields of mathematics and theoretical physics such as representation theory (the study of matrices) and algebraic geometry (the study of systems of polynomial equations). This rich connection to other fields is one of the attractive features of this problem.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Low dimensional topology is the study of objects such as knots in 3-space. A knot in this case consists of a tangled shoelace whose ends have been glued together. One of the main questions in this subject involves finding mathematically provable ways of distiunguishing between different knots.

Although this question might seem a bit naive at first and perhaps a bit unmotivated it turns out to have deep connections to other, seemingly unrealted fields in mathematics. One of these fields is representation theory. This is a vast generalization of linear algebra which is used to study the symmetry of objects.

More recently, the concept of categorification has permeated the field of representation theory (as well as other related subjects). The basic idea here is to replace vector spaces (one of the pillars of representation theory) with categories. This process is called categorification.The advantage of doing this is that categories are much richer objects which allow one to see deeper structure which was invisible earlier.

The research supported by the current award attempted to develop this concept of categorification in the context of representation theory with the aim of applying it to low dimensional topology. The techniques developed are also applicable to other areas such as algebraic geometry. More precisely, one can use tools in categorified representation theory to understand categories that show up in algebraic geometry (a seemingly unrelated area). Thus we are able to relate our work to other fields.

One of the main accomplishments of our research is a categorification of a construction in representation theory known as the Frenkel-Kac-Segal construction. This construction involves something called vertex operators which have been used in the past in the study of knots and, more generally, 3-manifolds. The fact that we can categorify the FKS construction indicates that there is a rich structure that is yet to be discovered in theory of vertex operators. This structure will allow us to develop a deeper understanding of knots and 3-manifolds.
